Literature Review: The dynamics of forward rates have been a central topic in financial mathematics, particularly in the context of derivatives pricing. The evolution of theoretical models reflects both the increasing complexity of financial markets and the need for more accurate pricing tools. This literature review traces the development of these models from the early short rate models to the sophisticated stochastic-volatility extensions of the SABR model, highlighting the interplay between theoretical advancements and market practices. The journey began with the short rate models of the 1980s, such as the Vasicek model and the Cox-Ingersoll-Ross (CIR) model, which provided a foundational framework for understanding interest rate dynamics. These models were based on the premise that the short-term interest rate follows a stochastic process, and they laid the groundwork for the no-arbitrage principle in interest rate modeling (Vasicek, 1977; Cox, Ingersoll, & Ross, 1985). However, these early models had limitations, particularly in their ability to fit the observed term structure of interest rates. This led to the development of the Heath-Jarrow-Morton (HJM) framework in the early 1990s, which modeled the entire forward rate curve rather than just the short rate. The HJM framework was a significant leap forward, as it allowed for a more flexible and realistic modeling of interest rate dynamics by directly incorporating the no-arbitrage condition (Heath, Jarrow, & Morton, 1992). Despite its theoretical elegance, the HJM framework posed practical challenges, particularly in terms of calibration and implementation. This spurred the development of the LIBOR market model (LMM), also known as the Brace-Gatarek-Musiela (BGM) model, which focused on modeling the dynamics of forward LIBOR rates. The LMM was more aligned with market practices, as it directly modeled the rates that were most relevant for pricing interest rate derivatives (Brace, Gatarek, & Musiela, 1997). The LMM's ability to capture the volatility smile and skew observed in the market made it a popular choice among practitioners. However, the financial crisis of 2007-2008 exposed the limitations of existing models, particularly in their treatment of volatility and correlation. This led to the development of more sophisticated models, such as the stochastic alpha beta rho (SABR) model, which introduced stochastic volatility to better capture the dynamics of forward rates (Hagan, Kumar, Lesniewski, & Woodward, 2002). The SABR model's flexibility in fitting the volatility smile and its tractability made it a widely adopted tool in the market. Recent advancements have focused on extending the SABR model to incorporate additional features, such as stochastic correlation and jumps, to better reflect the complexities of modern financial markets (Antonov, Konikov, & Spector, 2015). Throughout this evolution, the development of forward rate models has been deeply influenced by the institutional setting of derivatives trading. Market practices, such as the use of Black's formula for cap and floor pricing, have shaped the direction of theoretical research. The interplay between theory and practice has led to models that are not only mathematically rigorous but also practically relevant. In conclusion, the theoretical modeling of forward rates has evolved significantly over the past few decades, driven by both academic research and market needs. While early models laid the foundational principles, later developments have focused on addressing the limitations of these models and incorporating more realistic features. The SABR model, in particular, has had a lasting impact on the financial theory of asset pricing, and its extensions continue to be an active area of research. As financial markets continue to evolve, it is likely that the modeling of forward rates will continue to adapt, incorporating new insights and addressing emerging challenges.
